content: in the middle of the room stands a single iron door atop a stone Dyess
surrounding the door three decorative spheres each with the shape of a hand
and printed upon it hey guys welcome back to another episode of black magic
craft you know us crafting the Emmys tend to put a lot of time and energy
into building complicated ornate things to use in our games and impress our
players but the truth is a lot of the time the most useful items end up being
those simple little things that you don't think too much about like a little
stone or a little ornamental decorative piece they end up making their way into
almost every game because they're so universally useful for me one of those
items is a simple iron door and it seemed play and the vast majority of my
games it's a simple little item but it implies importance and its imposing and
it makes players want to progress to the next stage or level or room in fact that
little scenario at the beginning of this video was a real encounter that I ran in
my last session using this door and if you're interested in that encounter and
want to find out more details about it I shot a behind-the-scenes session recap
for my patreon supporters and it is available through my patreon the point
however is that a simple iron door can be used in every game so let's build an
iron door so I took my template cut it out and glued it to some chipboard this
way I could reuse this template over and over again and make a whole bunch of
these doors using the template as a guide I cut out the segments of the door
from some foam core and I used the higher quality foam core where the paper
doesn't peel off this would make the whole thing much stronger these doors
have three pieces one solid one in the middle and the two frames on the front
and the back using the outer piece as a guide I
traced out the shape of the door on the center solid piece this way I could draw
a line right down the middle of it and then score it with an exacto knife and
run a pencil down it to bevel the edges this would make it look like the solid
piece is actually two separate doors I then assembled the whole thing with hot
glue basically by making a hot glue door sandwich I cut some strips of
construction paper at various widths this would be used to hide all the edges
of the foam as well as to add some decorative elements and I used one of
these strips to cut some hinges for the store I cut my first one just kind of
eyeballing it and then I used that one as a template to make the rest to attach
the thinner inner strips to the door frame I just brushed on some PVA glue
when it came to doing the wider strip that ran along the outside I first
folded the piece and then attached it using hot glue I ran some strips on the
face of the door and this didn't hide anything but it did add some depth to
the piece and made it look like it was constructed out of some various layers
of Steel rather than just one solid chunk and I wanted this thing to look
like it had been constructed with a whole bunch of little screws or rivets
so I was able to do this by just poking a bunch of little holes using a pushpin
to create the look of larger rivets that would be more noticeable and actually
stick out instead of just being an indent I used these tiny little
decorative gems that I got from Michael's a really long time ago
basically you just want to get the smallest ones that you can find and you
can then take them and super glue them in place at anywhere there's a joint or
where you want it to look like there's a rivet like on the hinges and these look
really great once this thing is painted up has a bit of dry brushing and some
washes on it for the door handles I use these little jewelry eyelet things that
I go to Michael's these make fantastic doorknobs or levers or knockers or
whatever they are absolutely perfect I just placed them on the foam core press
them in a little bit to make a bit of an indent and then just drop some superglue
on them to lock them in place I wanted the door to have some torch holders on
it so I grabbed the smallest syndra chol bead I had on hand this one is really
nice because I had a kind of design on it as well same thing as the handles I
pushed them in place into the foam to create a bit of an indent and then I
just dropped in some super glue to glue it to the door frame now because this
was a cylinder glued to a flat paper surface I was a little bit concerned
about the strength of it and it possibly shearing off so I used the old super
glue and baking soda technique to create a super strong welded plastic bond
this piece was really sturdy and it didn't have any exposed foam on it so I
didn't put any Mod Podge on it I just took it right outside and primed the
whole thing using rust-oleum gray primer now the reason that I primed it out
using gray is because I wanted to paint this out using a gunmetal metallic and
under coating it with the gray meant that I would only need to put on one
coat of this metallic after the gunmetal I used some brighter silver to dry brush
the entire thing and pull out some of those higher details then I used this
chocolate brown metallic color which is kind of like a bronze to pick out some
of the individual details like the hinges the handles and some of the
rivets I use that same bronze color to lightly dab and dry brush across the
whole piece to give it some tonality so it didn't look like it was all just the
same kind of silver after that I added a little bit of rust to the piece and this
I just did with some bright orange that I mixed a little bit with the metallics
and just sparingly dabbed on in the lower portions of the door and some of
the raised bits I finished off the paint job with a black wash this is black with
a lot of dark brown in it and this would really aged the piece and get in all the
nooks and crannies and make it look a little bit cooler all around
then it was time to get to work to make the torches and to make these I use some
toothpicks I have to sand down the toothpicks a bit so that they would fit
in the hole in those beads that I had glued to the door so I used my dremel
tool for this but you could get away doing this by hand it would just take a
little bit longer I cut the toothpicks to length and I
used some hot glue to create the flame I just put a little dab of hot glue on the
end let it cool down a bit and then using the hot nozzle from the glue gun I
kind of teased up and created a flame like texture to paint the fire I did the
basic fire painting technique which is a base coat of white followed by a yellow
and then a dry brushing of orange and a very light dry brushing of red a lot of
people especially new people to painting tend to do this in the reverse because
normally when you're painting things you go from dark to light but flames is not
one of those things that you want to do that with you want to start with yellow
and finish in red if you want it to look like a real flame I really wanted to do
some object source lighting on the door I wanted it to look like the torches
were actually lighting this thing up and I don't have a lot of experience with
this I've done it on a few minis by hand but I had just got a brand new airbrush
set up in the mail that day I decided to learn to use my new airbrush by trying
out object source lighting on a piece I had just finished making and I didn't
really know what I was doing but I did have my old door to test on I got it to
a point that I thought looked pretty decent and I glued the torches in place
and touched up a little bit of paint on them after that I took it outside and
sprayed the whole thing with a matte varnish clear coat to seal everything in
hold on a second there is actually one last step that I did on this thing that
I neglected to film after completing it I put this on the shelf and moved on I
was painting miniatures one night and I glanced up at the shelf and I looked at
it and the object source lighting that I had done just looked kind of ridiculous
it was way too bright and it just looked like yellow blobs I was a bit bummed out
at the time I was putting a brown wash on some miniatures and I thought maybe
if I give this thing another coating of a wash it will improve that object
source lighting so I gave it a coat of wax earth shades by Citadel cause that's
what I was using it's a dark brown wash and lo and behold it improved the
lighting effect greatly it really muted the yellow and made it look quite a bit
more believable and less ridiculous I still don't think it's perfect but I
think it saved this project from looking really dumb so I'm glad I did it I think
it's not bad for a first try at airbrushing lighting effects let's zoom
in for the close-ups I promise you if you make one of these you will use it a
lot it is incredibly handy and it will be a fantastic addition to your DM
arsenal if you want to pick up any tools or supplies that I use in this and other
builds head on over to Blackmagic crafts dot CA there I have my essential
equipment store where I link to all of the things that I use and recommend and
purchasing through those links helps fund this channel the other way you can
fund these videos is by supporting black magic crafts on patreon it is the funds
graciously given by the people on patreon that allow me to dedicate so
many hours each week to building filming and producing these videos for the
community I'd love to have your support and I'd love to have you as the newest
member of the black magic craft fellowship
that's it for this week guys I hope you found this video entertaining
